Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: From Acorus to Zingiber - Assembling the Phylogeny of the Monocots
Award.AbstractNarration:
Monocots (including such groups as grasses, palms, orchids, and philodendrons) include more than 65,000 species of flowering plants, occur in almost all habitats, and provide the great majority of the human diet. A definitive family tree for this group will be developed and used to understand the broad-scale evolution of monocots over geologic time. A total of 23 genes in 601 species, whole chloroplast genomes in 175 species, and all genes expressed in 50 species will be sequenced and used to reconstruct the evolutionary history of this group. Additionally, phenotypic data from living and fossil species will be collected, and all data will be analyzed integratively to provide a comprehensive understanding of monocot evolution.

The resulting family tree will provide the foundation for many new studies in physiology, ecology, biogeography, and genomics of flowering plants. Web access to all data and results will be provided to researchers and K-12 teachers and students. Several post-doctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduates (with a focus on women and minorities) will be trained, and four young faculty will be supported. A museum exhibit on the evolution of flowering plants will be produced for high-profile venues in New York, Chicago, Denver, and Berkeley, and a children's monocot garden exhibit will be developed at the New York Botanical Garden. Posters illustrating monocot diversity and evolution will be distributed to colleges, and staff will give talks at public high schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, a study of the diversity and evolutionary history of monocots, involved investigators from several institutions, including Cornell University, The New York Botanical Garden, The University of Georgia, The University of Wisconsin, The University of Missouri, and others. Here we describe the outcomes of portions of the overall project principally conducted by investigators at Cornell University. Principal Investigator Gandolfo worked on the fossil record of the monocots. In her research she emphasized identification of the oldest known records of major groups, in order to understand their origin and diversification in deep time. Dr. Gandolfo and her collaborators determined several fossils for dating the "monocot tree of life". They also described the oldest record worldwide for the Subtribe Attaleinae, Tribe Cocoseae of the palm family (Arecaceae), and the first records of fossil leaves (Aquaephyllum auriculatum; Araceae subfamily Limnoideae; see photo 1) and the oldest record of Pandaniidites pollen grains (see photo 2), which are aquatic members of the aroid family (Araceae).  The latter two are both first records for the Southern Hemisphere.  Dr. Gandolfo included female undergraduate and graduate students in her investigations, two of them from minority backgrounds.  Principal Investigator Davis conducted studies of DNA sequences of genes from the chloroplasts of a wide range of plant species. We focused on the palm family (Arecaceae), the orchid family (Orchidaceae), the ginger family (Zingiberaceae) and its close relatives, such as banana and canna, and on the grass family (Poaceae) and its close relatives. This effort involved several people, and it contributed to the training of a post-graduate associate who is now a research professor at West Virginia University, a graduate student who is currently completing her studies, and an undergraduate student who is now a graduate student studying orchid diversity at the University of Wisconsin.  One result of our studies was the placement of the palm family in a precise position within the evolutionary tree of monocots. This family, a key element in tropical ecosystems, which includes the species that produce coconuts and dates, among many others, is unique in a number of ways, including structurally complex leaves and the large, woody-textured tree-like stature of many species.  Although well characterized as a family within the monocots, the palms have never been placed reliably in a particular location within this group. Our studies have determined that the closest relatives of the palms are a small Australian family (Dasypogonaceae) that has a standard lily-like form (see photo 3, Calectasia). The link between these two groups contributes to our understanding of the overall diversification history of monocots, and to the origin of the palm family.  The combined fossil and DNA data collected for this study have contributed to an understanding of the evolutionary history of the monocots, as well as to detailed relationships within several monocot families. These studies determine historical patterns of diversification of these groups, and reveal the tempo and dynamics of evolution of the plant groups and their genes. They also demonstrate the timing and locations of past evolutionary events, which in turn sheds light on the history of continental movements, climate, and habitat evolution.
